items.title: What if all patterns composed freely?
items.content:
You'd design: Pick any 3 patterns, combine them, expect success.
Why this fails: Patterns make assumptions. CC Mirror assumes it's the only orchestrator. Gas Town assumes the same. Two orchestrators = chaos.
Hidden constraint revealed: The matrix exists BECAUSE composition is not free.

items.title: The simplest useful combination
items.content:
Minimal: Subagents + nothing else.
Next step: Add Hooks for observability.
Everything beyond: Optimization for specific use cases.

items.title: Nader Dabit: Mobile + Cloud combo
items.content: Git Worktrees + Hooks (Poke) + Cloud VM. Manages multiple feature branches from iPhone. Push notifications when Claude needs input. "I ship more from my couch than my desk."

items.title: INV-003: External state > internal memory
items.content: Ralph, CC Mirror, Gas Town all share this invariant. That's WHY they can compose with Hooks and Worktrees. Same principle, same architectural choice, compatible foundations.

items.title: Matrix = Database compatibility chart
items.content:
"Documented" = Native driver exists
"Synergistic" = Compatible via adapter
"Possible" = Requires custom integration
"Anti-pattern" = Incompatible architectures

If you've chosen databases for a stack, you already understand this matrix.

items.title: At 3+ patterns, interaction effects dominate
items.content:
2 patterns: Manageable interaction surface
3 patterns: 3 pairwise interactions to track
4+ patterns: Combinatorial explosion

Implication: Don't add pattern 4 until patterns 1-3 are rock solid.

items.title: One constraint → The whole matrix
items.content:
ROOT: Orchestrators assume exclusive control
→ CC Mirror + Gas Town is anti-pattern
→ Ralph + CC Mirror (simultaneous) is anti-pattern
→ Choose ONE orchestration layer
→ Hooks/Worktrees/Memory are orthogonal
→ That's why they compose with everything

items.title: Setup Cost vs. Capability
items.content:
Simple combo (Hooks + HUD): 5 minutes setup, limited capability
Medium combo (Ralph + Worktrees): 1 hour setup, significant capability
Complex combo (Full Stack): 4+ hours setup, maximum capability

Heuristic: If you're not using the capability daily, you've over-invested.

items.title: Understanding ROI
items.content:
Beginner: "What's the best combination?"
→ The highest ROI for YOUR stage
Intermediate: "Why is Gas Town 3/5 ROI?"
→ High setup + maintenance for most use cases
Advanced: "When IS Gas Town worth it?"
→ 10+ agents, $50-200/day budget, Stage 7+
Staff: "ROI isn't fixed, is it?"
→ Correct. ROI varies by project, team, timeline.

items.title: Ralph + Hooks + Claude-Mem
items.content:
Works: Yes, with caveats.
Benefit: Hooks notify, Claude-Mem provides semantic project memory.
Danger: Redundant state tracking. progress.txt + Claude-Mem = double overhead.
Recommendation: Choose one memory mechanism. progress.txt for simple, Claude-Mem for semantic.

items.title: CC Mirror + Git Worktrees
items.content:
Works: Yes, synergistic.
Benefit: Each worker in own worktree = true filesystem isolation.
Danger: Requires custom integration (assign worktree paths to tasks).
Recommendation: Worth the medium effort for parallel production work.

items.title: If you use CC Mirror AND Gas Town
items.content:
IF: You configure both orchestrators
THEN: Both try to assign tasks to agents
THEN: Agents receive conflicting instructions
THEN: Work is duplicated or dropped
FINALLY: System produces garbage, you debug for hours

The fix: Choose ONE orchestrator. Never both.

items.title: Ryan Carson: Ralph + Subagents
items.content: Untangle Legal Agent. Main Ralph loop spawned security-auditor and test-writer subagents per iteration. "The parallel exploration within sequential iterations was the unlock."

items.title: How combination value perception evolves
items.content:
Week 1: "This setup took forever. Was it worth it?"
Week 2: "Starting to see time savings."
Month 1: "I can't imagine going back."
Month 3: "This is just how I work now."

Don't judge ROI by week 1. Judge by month 1.

items.title: How combinations fail (gradually)
items.content:
100% working: All patterns functioning
90%: Occasional hook miss (you don't notice)
70%: State sync issues (intermittent bugs)
50%: Resource conflicts (visible failures)
CLIFF: System deadlock (total failure)

Critical: Degradation is invisible until 50%.

items.title: If this combination isn't working
items.content:
Too complex? → Drop to single pattern first
Orchestrators fighting? → Remove one completely
Context exploding? → Move operations to subagents
ROI not materializing? → Simpler combination or single pattern

items.title: When adding patterns flips from help to hurt
items.content:
1-2 patterns: Clear benefit, manageable complexity
3 patterns: Peak ROI for most users
4 patterns: Diminishing returns start
5+ patterns: Maintenance cost > capability benefit

THE INFLECTION: ~3 patterns
Detection: Spending more time debugging combos than doing work?

items.title: What if hooks were project-level only?
items.content:
You'd design: Each project configures its own hooks independently.
Why this fails: Subagents don't inherit project hooks. Your multi-agent setup becomes blind.
Hidden constraint revealed: Global hooks exist BECAUSE subagent isolation breaks inheritance.

items.title: If you skip global hook configuration
items.content:
IF: Configure hooks at project level only
THEN: Subagents don't see the hooks
THEN: No notifications from worker agents
THEN: You think system is broken
FINALLY: Hours debugging a "bug" that's just config

The fix: Always configure hooks at ~/.claude/settings.json

items.title: UNSOLVED: Claude-Mem + Subagents
items.content:
The question: Should subagents share Claude-Mem with parent? Or have isolated memory?
Why it's hard: Shared = context pollution. Isolated = lost learnings.
Current best practice: No one knows yet. This cell is "Unexplored" for a reason.

items.title: The Composition Paradox
items.content:
THE DILEMMA:
- More patterns = more capability, more failure modes
- Fewer patterns = less capability, more predictable

WHY NO PERFECT ANSWER:
Interaction effects are emergent. You can't predict them from individual pattern behavior.

Accept that some compositions will surprise you. Plan for debugging time.

items.title: Understanding orchestration collision
items.content:
Beginner: "Why can't I use both?"
→ They both want to be the conductor.
Intermediate: "What if I partition agents?"
→ State sync becomes nightmare.
Advanced: "Has anyone made it work?"
→ No documented successful case.
Staff: "Is Gas Town ever worth it?"
→ Only at 10+ agents, Stage 7+, $50-200/day.

items.title: Steve Yegge on Gas Town threshold
items.content: "If you have any doubt whatsoever, then you can't use it." Gas Town is for Stage 7+. 10+ agent experience. Significant budget ($50-200/day). Comfortable with chaos. If any of these are missing, use CC Mirror.

items.title: What if you jumped straight to "Full Stack"?
items.content:
You'd design: Ralph + CC Mirror + Worktrees + Hooks + Claude-Mem from day 1.
Why this fails: You don't understand any pattern deeply. Debugging is impossible. Cost explodes.
Hidden constraint revealed: Staged progression exists because understanding compounds.

items.title: Pattern stages = Software architecture levels
items.content:
Stage 1-3 (Beginner): Monolith (simple, works)
Stage 4-5 (Intermediate): Modular monolith (organized, maintainable)
Stage 6-7 (Advanced): Microservices (complex, powerful)

You don't start with microservices. Neither should you start with Gas Town.

items.title: If combinations feel overwhelming
items.content:
Overwhelmed by choice? → Start with Subagents only
Want observability? → Add Hooks + HUD (15 min)
Want overnight runs? → Ralph + Hooks (30 min)
Want parallelism? → CC Mirror + Subagents (built-in)

Each path is complete on its own. Add complexity only when needed.

items.title: All high-ROI combos share this trait
items.content:
Ralph + Hooks: 5/5 ROI
Hooks + Subagents: 5/5 ROI
CC Mirror + Subagents: 5/5 ROI

The pattern: All use Hooks or have built-in observability. You can't optimize what you can't see.

items.title: How stage-appropriate combos feel over time
items.content:
Week 1 (Stage 3 trying Stage 7 combo): "I'm so advanced!"
Week 2: "Why isn't this working?"
Week 4: "I should have started simpler."

Week 1 (Stage 3 using Stage 3 combo): "This seems basic."
Week 2: "But it actually works..."
Week 4: "Solid foundation. Ready for Stage 4."
